isis.stitle: CE 200 AND CE 300 BUS BODY COMPONENTS - Maintenance - Heaters and Accessories

svcprocinfo.para: All heating systems used in the vehicles are hot water type. This type system depends on the vehicle's engine to generate heat from the engine coolant or antifreeze. The engine coolant is pumped through the heater hoses, then to the heaters. The primary heating system is plumbed in a "series water flow" system. In this type of system, the heater coolant supply hose is routed to each heater and returns to the engine after exiting the last heater in the system.
Heaters are made up of tube and fin type coils. When the coolant flows through the coils, the blowers move air across the fins of the coil and pick up the heat from the coolant.

This section is for the repair and maintenance of the bus interior heaters. It is advised that caution be taken during any repairs or maintenance to the heater system and that the recommended procedures as defined in the manufacturer's instruction manual be followed.

svcsubproc.title: Driver Side Heater
svcsubproc.para: The driver side heater unit is located directly to the left of the driver position, and below the left wing switch panel and driver storage compartment.

figure.caption: Figure 198. Driver Side Heater Main Heater Assembly

svcsubproc.title: Step Well Heater (Optional)
svcsubproc.para: The optional step well heater is located at the bus entry step well and is controlled from the driver environmental and climate control panel located between the driver side storage compartment and the driver's left wing switch panel.

svcsubproc.title: Under Seat Heaters
svcsubproc.para: The under seat heaters are located along the driver side of the bus in various locations depending on the length of the bus body. The heaters are located under a passenger seat and protected by a screened cover to protect them from damage.

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. AUXILIARY UNDER SEAT HEATER COVER PLATE
3. UNDER SEAT HEATER LOWER COVER AND AIR INLET

svcsubproc.title: Rear Body Heaters (Optional)
svcsubproc.para: Rear body optional heaters are generally used in conjunction with wheelchair access doors.

svcsubproc.title: Maintenance
svcsubproc.para: It is recommended that the heating system be inspected annually. However, more critical areas, such as around the engine, should be inspected on a regular basis. Filters should be removed and cleaned regularly.

step2.para: The heater coils are most efficient when the coils, fins and air flow passages are kept clean and free of dirt and dust. The coils should be cleaned with a soft flow compressed dry air or vacuum and a soft brush. Damaged fins should be straightened to prevent air flow restrictions.
All heater hoses should be inspected for kinks and chafing that will cause failure. Hoses should be replaced when cracks or permanent distortions are found.

Hoses and clamps should be checked regularly. Hoses may appear in good condition on the outside, but the inside may be partially deteriorated. If there are any doubts about the condition of the hoses, replacements should be made. Clamps should be inspected to ensure they are strong enough to hold a tight connection.
Motors are essentially maintenance free and do not require any lubrication or cleaning. However, excessive vibration caused by damaged blowers, wheels, and fans can cause motor damage.
Switches are maintenance free, but can be damaged by water and loose wire connections. Loose wires cause the component to require more amperage than normal. Inspect on a regular basis.

Defroster fans can be mounted on the bulkhead above the driver. The fans should be kept clean of dirt and dust. The metal cage can be removed for blade cleaning. Bend the metal lock clamps to remove the metal cage.

The antifreeze mixture of the coolant system is a 50/50 mixture of antifreeze and water. The mixture will protect the unit to -40 degrees F. For added protection in colder climates, refer to the engine coolant section.

svcsubproc.title: Troubleshooting
svcsubproc.para: Typically when a school bus does not have heat or air flow, several steps should be taken to eliminate the problem. Use the steps below as a problem solving guide.

warning.para: Use the following procedure to remove the pressure-type cap from the radiator. Always allow the engine to cool first. Wrap a thick, heavy cloth around the cap. Push down, loosen cap slowly to the first notch position; then pause a moment. This will prevent possible scalding by hot steam or water, which can cause injury and/or property damage.

step2.para: Check the heater hose gate valves. Make sure they are open (supply and return).
Check the coolant level. Make sure the coolant system is full and flowing.
Touch the heater hoses and feel for heat at the engine supply hose.
Inspect the heater hose routing for kinked hose that could block coolant flow.
Make sure the booster pump is operating correctly if present.
Open the bleeder valve and check for air in the heater hose (air lock).
Check engine operating temperature gauge and compare to air flow from heaters.
Check the butterfly valve and actuating cable for proper operation.

para.emph: No Air Flow from Heater Vents or Ducts

step2.para: Check the circuit breaker or fuse.
Check the switch.
Check the blower motor.
Check the resistor.
Check the harness connections for an open circuit.
Repair any items that are not functioning as required.

svcsubproc.title: Heater / Defroster and Blower Motor Access Procedures
svcsubproc.para: Each blower assembly has a resistor that controls the speed of the rotor. The defroster / step switch is a three-speed switch with a three-post resistor. When checking for speed variation, check all three speeds. Use a multi-meter to check the resistor. Refer to the IC Bus Troubleshooting Guide.

svcsubproc.title: Access Main Front Heater / Defroster Blower Motors and Resistors Assembly
svcsubproc.para: To access the driver / main heater assemblies use the following steps:

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. LEFT HAND SWITCH PANEL COVER MOUNTING SCREWS

step2.para: Locate all surface mounting screws at base of drivers heater panel ( Fig. 202, Items 4 and 5).
Loosen and remove the filter cover mounting screws.
Lift filter cover panel away from heater assembly.
Remove filter.

svcsubproc.title: Auxiliary / Midship Heater Motor Access
svcsubproc.para: To gain access the auxiliary heater motor or resistors, use the following steps.

step1.para: The auxiliary and/or midship heaters may vary in location. The rear auxiliary heaters when used with the wheelchair access door may be a vertically wall mounted assembly. The under seat heaters will be mounted under the standard passenger seat assembly. Depending on the type service the seat may or may not require removal.

step2.para: Locate the passenger seat above the heater assembly.
Flip the seat cushion up by adjusting the seat clip.
Remove the heater cover ( Fig. 200, Item 1) panel mounting screws.

figure.caption: Figure 203. Under Seat Heater Motor Access (84,500 BTU SHOWN)

step2.para: Remove the screws that secure the heater to the floor.
Remove the heater panels upper and lower, exposing the internal parts.
Locate the heater motor and disconnect the wire leads from the resistor.
Remove the motor casing nuts that secure the motor to the shroud.
Remove the fan from the motor shaft by using a small Allen wrench and turning the set screw counter-clockwise.
Remove the fan motor.

svcsubproc.title: Optional Step Well Heater Assembly
svcsubproc.para: To access the step well heater assembly, check for optional components that may be existing and have to be removed to gain access to the step well heater.

step1.para: To remove, clean or change step well heater filter use the following procedure.

step2.para: Locate the 3 filter plate mounting screws.

step3.para: To install filter reverse steps 1 through 3.

para.emph: Remove Step Well Heater Blower Assembly

figure.caption: Figure 205. Step Well Blower Motor Assembly

step3.para: Remove the optional assist handrail (if applicable).
Remove the fire extinguisher and mounting bracket (if applicable).
Remove the mounting screws along the lower edge of passenger entry dash panel.
Loosen and remove the mounting screws on face plate (cover weldment).
Loosen and remove the defroster hose clamps attaching defroster hose to front face plate.
Disconnect the harness plug connection to dual wheel blower assembly (if blower is to be removed).
Loosen and remove the five dual wheel blower mounting screws attaching the blower assembly to the case weldment. Remove the dual wheel blower assembly.

step2.para: The supply lines to and from the step well heater coil should be closed, prior to removal procedure.
Follow the procedures above to access the heater coil. To remove the heater coil:

step3.para: Locate the four mounting screws on the coil assembly bracket. Loosen and remove the mounting screws.

calloutgroup.callout1: 9. HEATER COIL SIDE COVER PLATE MOUNTING SCREWS

step3.para: Partially remove the heater coil assembly to gain access to the hose clamp connection to the supply and return lines.

entry.para: Hose not warm to the touch.
Check heater cut-off valves (open) to make sure they are open. Check the butterfly valve for proper operation.
Check coolant level and hoses for indications of coolant flow.
Check for kinks and air blockage.
Blower motor has one speed only.
Check booster pump and hose routing.
Air in the heater hose system.
Remove the surge tank cap, fill tank, start engine, open valves, bleed heater at bleeder valve.

svcsubproc.title: Upholstery Care and Cleaning Recommendations
svcsubproc.para: The upholstery vendor has supplied a list of solvents that are safe to use when cleaning the upholstery. These solvents, if properly used, will not harm the finish of the material. These solvents include:

step1.para: Wash with mild soap and hot water to remove ordinary dirt, grime, etc.
Stubborn stains should be cleaned with alcohol. Odorless Mineral Spirits or VM&P Naphtha can be used to remove paint, tar, gum, shoe polish, etc. if alcohol does not remove the stain.
Isopropyl Alcohol and Denatured Alcohol are especially recommended for cleaning stubborn dirt and stains.
Never clean upholstery with polish remover, Graffiti Eater strong caustic or acidic agents or any cleaners with active solvents like MEK, Tolual, gasoline, etc.
